description: The Mesrop Mashtots Institute of Ancient Manuscripts, Armenia's most important museum housing 23,000 manuscripts and scrolls. Named after the creator of the Armenian alphabet in 1962, the repository contains manuscripts in Armenian, Persian, Syriac, Arabic, Greek, Georgian, Russian, Hebrew, and other languages.
highlights: Gospel of Etchmiadzin from 6th century with oldest illustrations and miniatures
Vehamor Gospel from 7th century - oldest complete Armenian manuscript
Charentir of Mush - largest manuscript at 70x55cm weighing 27.5kg
Tiny 1434 Calendar measuring just 4x3cm and weighing 19 grams
UNESCO World Book of Memory recognition since 1997
tips: Allow 1-2 hours to properly explore the collection
Photography may be restricted in certain areas
Consider hiring a guide to understand the manuscripts' significance
Statue of Mesrop Mashtots stands prominently in front
Manuscripts cover history, geography, philosophy, science, medicine, and law
vibe: A reverent sanctuary of knowledge where ancient wisdom lives on parchment, offering a profound connection to Armenian intellectual and spiritual heritage spanning millennia
